Content-Type: text/plain;
	charset="us-ascii"
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit

I don't know if this will be of any help, or not.
 
Timothy Masters wrote a book back in 1995 that has been very helpful to me,
especially in his description of Welch data windows. The book is entitled
"Neural, Novel and Hybrid Algorithms for Time Series Predictions" published
by John Wiley and Sons.  It has some excellent insight especially in the
finance domain.
 
I'm not involved in finance, just pattern identification in evolutionary
dynamical systems, of which economies and markets may be categorized.
 
 
Ken Lloyd


  _____  

From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
shanemcdonaldryan
Sent: Monday, July 27, 2009 7:59 AM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Re: Time Series Prediction and NEAT


  

Spent quite a bit of time working on this problem. Not too successful.

Go to Metatrader4.com and learn the meta trader language (pretty much c). It
will allow you create scripts and backtest with historical data to see how
they perform. If you write a DLL you can even call NEAT via Metatrader.

I used to work for a company trading futures and I can tell you all the easy
data mining type trading strategies are tapped out. You'll have to find
something interesting to make it work. Ideally some sort of leading
indicator or something very strongly co-ordinated so you can do pairs
trading.

Sliding window would be my advise. But that is a pretty inconsequential
detail as you'll need much more than a sliding window to make money in my
experience.

Tell me how you do and I can give you my advice. Though take it with a grain
of salt because I didn't make my billions through this :)

Regards,

Shane

--- In neat@yahoogroups. <mailto:neat%40yahoogroups.com> com, "gururise"
<gururise@...> wrote:
>
> Hello,
> Browsing the archives, its obvious other's have worked on this problem
using NEAT with varying degrees of success. I'm using the rtNeat C++ package
under linux and am trying to evolve a time-series predictor applicable to
either the stock market or forex markets.
> 
> Most of the published research used Neural Networks trained via backprop.
These networks typically used a sliding window technique. For example, if
you have 1000 days of historical data, a sliding window of 100 would feed
the first 100 days of data as input, and the 101st day would be the
predicted output from the net. Then the window would slide by 1 day, and you
feed the next 100 days and so on an so forth. 
> 
> I've been trying to use a similar technique with NEAT with very limited
success. For inputs, I use change in price and normalized volume. The
fitness function is basically the inverse of the mean squared error of the
predicted outputs vs. the actual data. The output is trying to predict the
change in price at the next time period (it could be positive or negative).
I've also switched from the default sigmoid activation function to a
bi-polar sigmoid activation that allows for outputs in the range of [-1,1].
> 
> How are others using NEAT for time series prediction? Are you using a
sliding window technique, or just have a large input with one output? Has
anyone had success using NEAT to evolve a time-series predictor?
>






------=_NextPart_000_0024_01CA0E92.CF82F280
